node.contents: I reassure you, it most definitely is atomic. It would be a critical bug if it was not. I expect you will find your code problem if you debug your code.

elements.contents: public boolean tryReleaseShared(int releases) { // Decrement count; signal when transition to zero for (;;) { int c = getState(); if (c == 0) return false; int nextc = c-1; if (compareAndSetState(c, nextc)) return nextc == 0; } }

comments.text: // Decrement count; signal when transition to zero for (;;) { int c = getState(); if (c == 0) return false; int nextc = c-1; if (compareAndSetState(c, nextc)) return nextc == 0; } }

node.contents: compareAndSetState calls which uses the same Unsafe class that backs the AtomicInteger and many other classes.

node.contents: If it was broken then a large portion of the java.util.concurrent are broken.

astNode.text: If it was broken then a large portion of the java.util.concurrent are broken.

node.contents: The fact that it's a data structure in java.util.concurrent is a dead giveaway, but the Java code uses an AbstractQueuedSynchronizer which helps to implement atomic operations, and the implementation is pretty straightforward once you read up on the queued synchronizer's API. It's definitely atomic :-)

astNode.text: The fact that it's a data structure in java.util.concurrent is a dead giveaway, but the Java code uses an AbstractQueuedSynchronizer which helps to implement atomic operations, and the implementation is pretty straightforward once you read up on the queued synchronizer's API. It's definitely atomic :-)
